newsitem.title: USA: CME lumber ends sharply lower in wake of hurricane.
newsitem.headline: CME lumber ends sharply lower in wake of hurricane.

text.p: CME lumber futures closed sharply lower, with limitless September down $12.80 per tbf, in the aftermath of Hurricane Fran, which hit North Carolina late Thursday.
"People were expecting more damage from the hurricane than what actually occurred," said Neil Schmaedick, forest products analyst with Smith Barney.

Insurance companies said preliminary estimates show losses from Fran will be manageable and not force companies into insolvency. State Farm Insurance, which has 16.5 percent of the North Carolina market, said losses will be less than the $455 million in claims caused by 1989's Hurricane Hugo.

Also, weighing on lumber futures was market talk of sagging cash prices for lumber species other than spruce, said Schmaedick. He said, however, that prices for deliverable spruce remain firm at $430 to $435 per thousand board feet.
Lumber closed down $12.80 to $8.10 per tbf with November off $8.90 at $388.00.
